Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 09:53AM fire-dancer wrote: purelove - I wanted to pop in and let you know I'm sorry you have to be making such difficult desicions...I DO encourage you to look into the nipple sparing mastectomy (NSM).  If you are a candidate for this particular surgery, it is a wonderful option for such a crappy situation ;) I underwent NSM in December, had tissue expanders (TE) and just got my implants the end of March.  My incisions are in the bottom crease of my breast and will be almost nonexistant when its all said and done, the natural droop of the breast will "hide" them pretty good :-)  It does take a bit to get used to the implants, I went from an A cup to a C, and am still trying to get used to them , but it's definitley not bad!  I was 36 years old at the time of BMX surgery and bounced back pretty well.  I still went to the gym 4 days a week (after 5 weeks off)  with TE's, albeit I had to alter the weights/endurance a bit!  I am cleared for the gym on Monday (3 weeks post-exchange) to ride the bike.  Then at 6 weeks post-exchange I am cleared for all activity, as long as I listen to my body!  It is a long road to recovery, but it sounds like you are healthy & young, and would hopefully bounce back ok.  I suggest getting PT if your PS recommends to avoid other issues.  I do have a winged scapula from surgery and will be doing PT when I am cleared for arm movements. I hope all goes well for you, these are hard choices re: what type of surgery you choose, but ask questions and know we are all here for you!

My one "healthy breast when pathology came back had abnormal cells, so that is considered ok, I guess.  This will always be a mystery to me.  Yes, I am 37, got BMX for my bday ;-) This year I told my husband don't buy me anything, I really don't need a piece of jewlery to remind me everyday that I got to spend my 37th under 5 or 6 hours of anesthesia!!!! But really...I don't want to put things like that out there to scare people, but it did happen & I think it's just that sometimes these things just happen.  I have dense breasts, maybe still being (relatively) young, who knows how the machines can't pick this stuff up...I asked my BS and she responded even the best machines don't see everything.  I am sure that you are watched very carefully and rest easy that you made a great decsision.  The LCIS was multifocal, so that led me to remove both breasts, basically it would have done me no good to just do one. Sorry if my thoughts are scattered, I am cleaning my house, trying to find a new razor for these crazy legs ;-) and heading off to friends for New Years with the family, it doesn't help that nowadays I move at the speed of mollasses, really - everything takes so darn long,,,and I digress yet again ;-) Gigi, I am wishing you the best for 2011...I am incredibly grateful this year for all of you and the continued support of this site - be well...

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 10:12PM fire-dancer wrote: Ilene, I wondered the same thing.  I will be asking my BS to clarify this before surgery, just to be 100%, but she explained that there is a 20% chance of in-situ/invasive cancer when she goes in, but of course pathology for that takes a week or so after surgery.  I don't know if SNB is recommended due to having ADH along with LCIS, (a strong family HX as well)  but when I asked about it she said that it is something that is more difficult to ever go back and do, and it would be wise to do at surgery.  I must say I wasn't thrilled for SNB, I am fearful of lymphedema, my mom suffers tremendously with it.  But my BS says my chances of LE are 1-2%.  I am also involed in a LE clinical study that will follow my progress over the years and will detcect any minor change before I would probably know it. sohardbnme, sorry for the delay in your recon, that must be difficult to process, I'm thinking of you... Tina, I still don't know how I'll work the recliner after surgery, I better try it out or I'll be stuck till help comes!  Be well, ladies!

I hope you go with what your heart tells you, only you know the path that will lead you...I just know mine, but the beauty of this place is that we are all different and can gather input from eachother to help with these tough times, be well & know I wish you the best!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 03:42PM fire-dancer wrote: Hi all, just wanted to comment on the snb, I didn't have any numbing sprays and it smarts for a moment, then it's over, I really think the idea of it is worse than the actual procedure, good luck! Today I headed out for a car ride and to help dh at the market for a quick trip, well...I came home and was ready for a nap!  I was only in the market for maybe 25 mins or so but I think the whole standing up-thing for a while weighed on my chest.  I've been taking tylenol during the day since yesterday (with the occasional ativan as a muscle relaxant) to get away from the percoset all the time.  I was feeling so weird and am finding the tylenol alone is working pretty well.  I also am waiting for the stool softeners to "kick in".  I am over the whole constipated-thing...ugh!, sorry if thats tmi :-)  I, too cannot wait to get rid of the drains, they are so uncomfortable & irritate my skin where they rub on my sides.  I go on monday to my PS and think I might lose 2 of the 4...fingers crossed! I am glad to see that the women who have come home are doing well! yay for you all and we are on the other side!!! To the women waiting, it is amazing how true it is that the hardest part (mentally) is the anticipation of surgery.  Although after surgery is a whole other can o' worms :-) I experienced a more calming feeling (once the morphine wore off and I was able to feel anything but loopy :-) I can honestly say that, having no regrets of the surgery, I am looking forward in a different way than before.  The wknd before surgery was all unknowns, and yes there are still a ton of unknowns with the pathology reports, TE's, etc. but there is a feeling of confidence that I'll get there and it will be ok...oh well, I hope this helps a bit, you are all brave and strong women and if there's another thing I've learned, once It was over, I looked deep within myself and "re-discovered" the faith I have in my own body and it's ability to heal & carry me through these times. This is my hope for each of you. wishing you all peace and good thoughts...

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 09:26AM fire-dancer wrote: Hi Andrea,  I have been experimenting with clothes, especially since I've had to go out with the drains and was trying to avoid looking like the "michelin man" all stuffed up in a sweatshirt,..geez, there is NOTHING attractive about those drains! Well, one thing that worked was taking some of my Target ribbed tank tops and cutting a "V" in the underarms by a couple of inches, it allowed me to shimmy them up and cover the drain tubing.  Then I would get a pair of jeans, and stuff the drains in the pockets :-) !!! Lastly, I wear some nice winter cardigan and casually button a few and it actually looks ok.  A scarf around my neck hanging in front hides my flat chest.  The other thing that worked great were "V" necked longsleeved  T's I bought at Marshalls or Target.  Big enough to get my arms & head thru, although by the end of the day I am sore as hell and need more assistance getting out of it than I did getting in it :-) With Christmas this week and busy times with the fam, I had to figure out how to get out of the house and not look "sick".  In fact, I highly advise going to the salon for a wash & blow-out, it worked wonders and my husband loved that he was off hair-duty...considering he is like Mr Mom right now! I have a question for everyone...how long were you told not to drive?  I am on 2 weeks now and still have 2 drains and I think I am supposed to wait to drive till the drains are out...my husbands worried he's going to have to hide the keys on me soon ;-)

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 11:01AM fire-dancer wrote: I agree...as my BS said, "I dodged a bullet".  I was fortunate that what was discovered was only DCIS.  If I had just done a lumpectomy, (that was suggested to me as a perfectly good course of action for the LCIS) I would have been walking around for who knows how long, while this undetected DCIS broke out and became invasive.  My BS was sure this would have happened sooner or later.  I figure, thinking back on my mother's cancer, she had IDC with some DCIS at 50 yrs (mastectomy/chemo)...I was 36 when this started for me, so I imagine that it would have just kept growing undetected, just like my mom's for how many years who knows till I felt a lump.  Statistics say that it takes about 10 years to actually feel a lump from BC.  I have mentioned this in conversation with friends while discussing what has been going on, not to scare them, but it was amazing to me how long you can walk around without ever feeling it, let alone Mamms possibly missing it along the way, which is my case...I am trying to get my 42 yr old sister to find a reputable breast ctr.  Since me, my mom, aunt & g-mother all had BC, I worry that she might not be getting the high-risk-surveillence she should be.  BTW, does anyone know what would/might be recommended for someone in a extremely high-risk situation? Just curious if anyone has had experience - thanks! But anyway...yes, it still amazes me how this can happen...
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 09:09AM fire-dancer wrote: ericavw - Glen Rock is in Bergen county, next to Ridgewood/Paramus area... ADH (atypical ductal hyperplasia) was another "marker" of my breast cells doing irregular things, they didn't want to cooperate and grow the right way, so it was another sign, like the LCIS it meant that I had a high risk for BC, and lo & behold, I had DCIS...sooo glad to be done with BMX, I also get the crazy sensations that my nipples can still feel the cold.  I said it yesterday to my husband, I can't feel a darn thing, but I SURE feel the same reactions randomly - so weird!!! I am so excited to be half-way through my fills.  I have some pointy areas of the TE sticking out, I look forward to when they smooth out and fill up.  I go every week and will be done (hopefully) by 1st week in Feb.  Then it's sit & wait.  But I should be able to do exchange sometime in late March or April I think.  I am soooo excited for squishy boobs! ;-) I am also trying to get my range of motion back.  I have gone to the gym and rode the bike a couple times. (I'm 5 weeks post BMX)  While I'm on there, I do my arm exercises. Or sometimes I hold a whopping 1 lb weight ;-)  I gotta say, I was tight in the chest area after, but not in pain.  I also find after a fill I am tighter, deinitley no pain, just tight in my muscles.  I am actually quite pleased with the way my body has reacted.  I get a heavy/sore feeling in the evenings, but I think that's normal, considering I go-go all day with my 5 & 7 yr old daughters :-) All in all it has been much more do-able than I anticipated.  Leading up to surgery I went to the gym religously - I framed it like I was training for a race.  I have always gone to the gym, but I was more intense on myself a few months leading up to BMX, and I do think it's helped a ton in my recovery. Well, all I can do is be glad I feel great today.  I know there is always a chance of a set back (infection, etc) along the way with the reconstruction, but I will cross that bridge if I have to.  Today all I can do is focus on how good I am doing and try to keep that in the front of my thinking.    Wishing you all the best...
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:00AM fire-dancer wrote: Glad to hear you are listening to your body...I have good & bad days, too...I think when this whole thing started I expected it to be the absolute worst thing ever, and it sure has been a struggle, but as long as I listen to my body & rest whenver possible I seem to be able to maintain.  I have spent the past month laying low and really limiting myself on social obligations, and I think it was the best thing I could do.  I need my sleep more than ever now ;-) I stopped taking the "hardcore" drugs about a week after surgery, but like clockwork, I am exausted and feeling the aches of the day by 4:00 everyday, I can't help it, I just go with it and try to slow down. I still rely on an Ativan to loosen my muscles at night every now and again, if it helps me relax to sleep, then I'll do it. I definitley believe that to heal we need our sleep. Some nights I wake up at like 2 or 3 am and since we all know there is practically no shifting to a "better" position I find it impossible to get back to sleep...those are the nights I wish I took a 1/2 an ativan before bed to relax more.  I have had a crick in my neck for a few days now from sleeping in a crappy position...I dream of the day I can sleep on my stomach...ahhh!!!  That's awesome you are doing PT.  I wasn't given any instructions about it, but I could see how that would be a help.  Oh, I love the idea of going for a breast massage...I travel to Boston to my PS and I know there are alot of resources I am probably not taking advantage of due to the fact travel can be a nightmare...I think I will look into it again and see if I can plan ahead... It sounds like you are doing just what you need to be, take care of yourself and rest, rest, rest!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 08:54AM fire-dancer wrote: Hi Ladies, I went to get aspirated and the PS opted to do my 1st fill instead.  The reason being that once you begin fills, there is less room for fluid to build up.  I was taken off guard b/c I thought my 1st fill would be next week, (for some reason I expected that I needed to mentally "prepare" for my 1st fill, weird, I know;-) I think it may have actually worked, I don't have as much fluid and the fill (60cc's) was doable and now I am at 110 cc's (PS put in 50cc's at surgery).  I will be going on Tuesday for my 2nd fill and will see how the fluid goes.  I actually think I am more comfortable/less burn than before the fill, the fluid was definitley making me uncomfortable... Nanny62 - I thought I had a weird spot under my arm, I thought it was fluid but it was the TE where it had kind of moved, there was fluid trapped around it so it made it feel softer/more malleable.  I was also told hard, pea sized spots under my armpits would be swollen nodes.  I did have SNB but from what I'm gathering, swelling of other nodes is normal in the beginning. Take_two - I agree, I think I've got pretty good movement but am trying to still be mindful of not doing too much...these weeks are critical to moving on in the healing process and as difficult as it is, I'm REALLY trying to enjoy a more "relaxed" lifestyle, so weird when I am usually moving & grooving all day long...and I agree, very soon this will be something that happened last year! Kim - hope you are feeling ok and getting comfort, rest while you can! eileen, thanks for your input - I wish you all a lovely new year!
Posts.Title: drains out & now fluid is building up - what to do? fire-dancer fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 03:39PM fire-dancer wrote: take_two - geesh, you are practically the exact same as me, down to the dates, my drains were out 12/23!  Sorry you are feeling uncomfortable, I definitley sympathize, the burning and tightness makes me uncomfortable.  I have like a pillow under my left arm and I cant even feel the bottom half of the TE, it's just all mushy & squishy, yuck, my right side isn't quite as bad, though, but still mushy around the expander...just when I thought I was turning a corner with the drains coming out.  I am hoping for the aspiration to work tomorrow...good luck to you and let me know how it goes... Thanks eileen1955,I feel like I could stand the burning pain, I agree, at night when I am laying down I find more comfort, but I have no option to rest often enough, the kids are off from school this week (kindergarten & 2nd grade) and it's nearly impossible, as much as I would LOVE to rest more.  I do feel worn out at times and was put on bed rest of sorts right before my drains were pulled due to high numbers, PS thought I was doing too much...I'm still trying to go as slow as possible, hope I can help the swelling stay down once it is aspirated. Thanks again and I truly wish you all well...it helps when I hear feedback from you all, at least I know I am not experiencing something totally off the radar

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 05:46PM fire-dancer wrote: I think I am becoming more uncomfortable, but the holidays were crazy with 2 young kids and travel, so I think I was a bit too busy, but I think how I feel is still in the realm of "normal".  My BS reminded me that I will have good days and some not-so-good...I am trying to not over-analyze every feeling. But yet I do it anyway ;-)  Nothing has really changed as far as pain, still feels like the 'let-down' feeling like when I nursed my daughters or a weird burning sensation, but tighter due to the swelling now.  I am not red at all and no other signs of something worse.  I go for my 1st fill in 7 days, so getting aspirated on wednesday should hold me over till I go for the 1st fill.  It's over an hour each way to the Dr with no traffic, and due to the blizzard all appts from today are double-booked for tomorrow, so I think I can make it till Wednesday. Thankd for your input - it truly is appreciated!
Posts.Title: drains out & now fluid is building up - what to do? fire-dancer fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 11:29AM fire-dancer wrote: So glad I could help :-) I wondered at 1st if it would work, but I had my best day (pain-wise) 48 hrs after the fill.  I was so worried I would be terribly uncomfortable, but it worked.  I still have some fluid build up but the rationale made sense and worked.  I agree, I have gathered  info here that I was not told from my docs and have felt so reassured and more confident that it's not "just me" that is experiencing this.  Enjoy the day!

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2010 08:08PM fire-dancer wrote: hi westieluv & welcome to a supportive and wonderful group of women!  I so agree, this path has led me to places I really never thought I'd be, but I'd say we are managing the best possible, huh?!?  I am definitley a different person than I was several months ago, but I guess that goes without saying, it's just a natural progression...I've been cooking up more food this wknd and making meals like the world is ending ;-) ...my lovely husband is perfect in many ways but a cook he is not! But, that is the least of my worries now I guess...be well this week in your preparations and I'm around if you need anything!  take care and we are all here for you!!!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 09:26AM fire-dancer wrote: Hi all & a warm welcome to the new december members!  I am home from the gym, which by the way was a nightmare...I just couldn't gather the energy for kickboxing, I was so distracted and felt "off".  I am trying to fit in the workouts since very soon there won't be the chance, but it really is feeling like "work" this week, I guess this stress is too big to be worked out with a good sweat at the gym... Zogo/Jane:  stay healthy!!! My DH is on the mend and my 7 yr old is sick with a cold...I'm just waiting for my 5 yr old to get the sniffles, too...I have had a bit of a stuffy head and runny nose for @ 10 days, I am hoping that since it has stayed pretty much the same that it is on it's way out.  I was so panicked this wknd that I started a thread on the surgery, before during & after section asking when surgery might be postponed. I got responses that it is usually if there is a fever or something significant.  Usually it is the call of the anesthesiologist, too.  I truly hope you stay healthy and drink LOTS of fluids! Annie62: yay to teaching your child to bike-ride! Its gotta feel good to know you've done the "big things" before surgery.  I spent the wknd decorating for the holidays & doing the tree, it was good familiy-time and much needed.  We just told our daughters this past wknd about surgery, kept it very simple and age-appropriate.  They seemed to take it well, I assume the questions will be when I get home and life is upside down for a while. I better get going, this week is all about getting the house in order & cleaning everything...I get the feeling that there are alot of us up to the same stuff, it is overwhelming how behind I feel, even though I think I've prepared alot already...ugh ...take care, everyone!!!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 04:14PM fire-dancer wrote: Hi oconnor2450, just wanted to pop on and say welcome...I too, am just a "little" anxious ;-) ...yup, pretty much when I'm not being mommy I am doing/planning/thinking about all this.  Sounds like that's a popular theme for many here!  This may sound silly or wierd, but I was organizing my dresser today to put the clothes I will need to access for the next weeks in the upper drawers so as not to rummage through everything.  Well, as I moved & rearranged I needed to make more space, so I packed up all (or most) of my bras that I assume I won't need for a while, if ever again.  It was bittersweet and kind of a good-bye at the same time.  I didn't expect to feel so sentimental about a bra but I was nostalgic. It also happened when I had PMS this past month, it was the last breast tenderness I assume I will ever experience...not that I'll miss it persay...but still, I was mindful of it being "the last". ...oh well, the 'big picture' is what I keep reminding myself...sorry if I got carried away, but I figured that there is really no where else I can voice these wacky things! thinking of each of you this evening!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2010 09:47AM fire-dancer wrote: Riley702 - smart idea, especially after surgery when you are all groggy it's good to have a reminder...my mom suffers from severe lymphedema in her arm and while I only had SNB 2 nodes on left, 1 on right, I fear the repurcussions of LE since I've seen how debilitating it LE can be, That sounds like something I need to do I'm allergic to bacitracin and even though it should be written ALL over my charts, everyone seems to want to still slab it on me.  I was in my PS office yesterday and the nurse attempted to put it on my drain wounds, I almost didn't even realize it till the last second...geesh, I don't need a hold-up like that to slow me down!  I'm very glad you are taking control! Tammy, I so understand the feelings going through your head right now, I can honestly say without ANY hesitation that, although you are in the thick of the anxiety-part of the journey, it gets better...I was just commenting to my husband how since surgery last Monday, I have never felt so light, the surgery anxiety has faded.  Although there are other obstacles after surgery, it feels different than how intensely I felt leading up to BMX, be good to yourself today, don't stress too much about what you might not finish around the house or whatever loose ends you might want to tie up, just be good to yourself, everything you are feeling is completely natural and soon you will be looking through a new perspective.  Wishing you all the best! oconnor2450 - so sorry about the unfortunate "upgrade"...hope that you get answers about what this all means, I'll be thinking of you!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 08:01PM fire-dancer wrote: crunchypoodlemama: don't get too upset yet - I also had a crater-like dip between my clavicle & my nipple-area, probably closer to my nip (?).  I pointed it out to my husband and couldn't believe what a big indentation it was.  I am now 2 weeks out and it has gone down tremendously.  There is still a minor "dip" but I think what you might be experiencing excess swelling, that's what I assumed it was and it went down over the course of time. Definitley point it out at your visit, I'll be curious to hear if it's the same thing I had, too...be positive & I hope that's all it is!  Also, I found the muscle relaxers worked way better than the hydrocodone, seemed to actually relax the area a bit more, also advil is a big help to take in conjunction, ask your Dr about it... I did not receive my path report as expected today. I spoke with the surgical coodinator who said, "oh we have it right here, Dr will call and discuss" and she was in surgery all day so now I have to wait another day...it's the last piece to this puzzle and I just need to know it... Anyone else feel like their chest is on fire? I have had a terrible burning sensation for 48 hours across my chest, not like a muscular thing, I asssume my confused nerves are trying to heal? But really I have no idea, it's difficult to relieve the pain with advil, but I'm trying, it seems I need another dose every 5 1/2 hrs at the longest, Since I am only taking 2 at a time I just keep this up to stay as comfy as possible I am also worried I might not lose my last 2 drains before xmas, I'm still putting out 40mm a day and need to be to 20mm for 48 hours before they come out - best start looking for clothes to hide the freakin' drains for the holidays,,,,
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 03:00PM fire-dancer wrote: I just wanted to update that I got my path back, I've been upgraded to DCIS, grade 2, several centimeters.  Due to the BMX there is no further treatment, I am still amazed that mamms, US & MRI's saw none of it.  DCIS was in 7 out of 12 sections taken for pathology of one breast.  The other breast was found to have abnormal cells/activity.  In the words of my BS I was a sitting duck, it was a matter of time till it became IDC.  I am the youngest diagnosis in my family now (36) out of my mom, aunt & g-mother.  I am working to get my 42 yr old sister into a facility that will meet her needs and take our family situation seriously to ensure she gets the surveillence she needs. Wow, I am pretty floored by this having gone unseen on the prior tests, but more than relieved that I followed thru with the BMX, I felt it in my gut and here it was. Thanks to all of you for the continued support...I feel blessed to have found BC.org!
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 06:49AM fire-dancer wrote: thinking of you dfwgal! tsundermann: so glad to hear positive news, it's amazing how when you emotionally feel stronger, how much it can change your outlook!  Lucky you on the drains, too! Crunchy - super-psyched for your clean margins!!!! It sounds like things are really going well, I'm going to check out some of the circulation-enhancing ideas - I've seen them on the NSM thread but wasn't "there" with surgery like I am now.  Good luck on the drains & nip! Zogo - aww, sorry you have a long day...hope you stay as comfortable as possible... Beacon800 -  I hear you, my BS is first-rate and was amazed at what was not seen on all the diagnostic tests, she commented that even the best machines aren't perfect.  The biopsy taken of LCIS was adjacent to DCIS, I'm truly amazed at my report.  The DCIS was scattered all over the breast...shocking that it was never picked up - dense breasts contribute to this I guess. And no, I require no further treatment, the margins were clear, it was all DCIS and my BS and I are going to meet after the holidays to discuss what future monitoring I will receive. I am more than grateful that I am sitting here in bed, trying to avoid sitting on the drains ;-), feeling the burning sensations & sharp "phantom?" pains that have arised with the BMX.  As crazy as the healing and TE's are, I wouldn't trade for anything!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 02:32PM fire-dancer wrote: I am writing from my bed...my PS wants to pull my last 2 drains tomorrow since they have been in since 12/06.  I am still producing close to 30cc on one side and that's hovering a bit too high.  Wish me luck that I can sit still, like bedrest till tomorrow.  I am cut off from any activity, the nurse thinks I am doing too much thus, no walking/excessive arm movement. And here I thought I was "behaving" ;-) ... I do wonder what happens if they pull the drains and I am still producing fluid?  Where will it go without a drain? I can't wait to spend the holodays drain-free. I foolishly got one tube wrapped around a doorknob yesterday -ouch!!! I was trying to get changed and my closet door was opened as I attempted to walk away...oh so cumbersome!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2010 05:55PM fire-dancer wrote: Thanks Carolyn & ArleneMarie ~I appreciate knowing your experiences, the fluid is clear, looks like just lymphatic fluid, just too much of it and after 2 1/2 weeks the PS doesn't want the drains hanging around anymore...hope all goes well! ...I have been trying to be good, it's such a difficult time of year to be still, we are leaving for Cape Cod for a extended family Christmas tomorrow,  lots of packing,  5 & 7 yr old girls who are over the top for Santa, school class parties, (I'm room mom) and a DH who works alot and I hate to have him come home to take care of all of us...I guess I have been trying to do more than I should, but I'm sure like the rest of you, it's difficult to lay low at one of the busiest times of the year...well, I hope you are all feeling well and recovery has been going smooth as possible!

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 04:33PM fire-dancer wrote: Welcome Rita & Summer - I am sorry that your path has led you to difficult decisions, but glad you found us, this is quite the amazing group of ladies! I went today for aspiration of excess fluid buildup and instead got my 1st fill, PS said the sooner we fill, the less room there is for fluid buildup.  I am at 110 cc's as of today, another 60cc's on Tuesday and every week thereafter if I can handle it, till I get to my desired size, I'm thinking full 'B'...I'm 5'6 and 120 lbs, not alot of room for a big set ;-) I'm very excited to be starting this new chapter, it is uncomfortable but manageable...we'll see how I feel tomorrow!!! I hope this evening finds you all well, wishing good thoughts upon each of you!

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 09:20AM fire-dancer wrote: Hi everyone! It's nice to hear about everyone's progress - hope all continues to go well... I've been doing quite well, my nipple-sparing BMX is healing great, my incsions seem to be doing fine, my pain is really minimal right now, I actually forget about the TE's alot of the day, of course they feel tight but I guess I am just getting used to this "new", although temporary -  me.  I go for a fill tomorrow.  I am at 270 cc's and am scheduled for 60 cc's more.  I missed a couple appts due to all this snow, so I am behind a bit.  I am contemplating asking if my PS will go a little more, like 100 cc's tomorrow, just to get back on track.  Who know's - either way I am glad right now to be feeling good, we'll see how I feel tomorrow !!! ;-) I've really been trying to get in some exercise, too.  I go to the gym 3 times a week and have been riding the bike about 10-15 miles each time, depending on my motivation ;-)  I was cleared for the bike about 3 weeks ago, so I have been really trying to make a point of NOT slacking too much.  I do my arm exercises from the PS while I ride to pass the time, I also sometime just hold 2 lb weights by my side just to remind me to engage my core and sit up straight.   I keep remembering something I read at the PS about standing tall, like a ballerina is great for you post-BMX, and considering I am a super-sloucher, this is probably good for me anyway!!! I really am not loving it, (at all) but I know that having some strength prior to BMX was helpful in recovery and I just don't want to lose it all before the exchange and I am out of exercise again for a month or longer. Hope everyone is staying warm, if you are experiencing this freezing weather - I am so all set with it now...snow today and MORE tomorrow...ugh! Be well, ladies!!!
